   2. We scan through the table looking for rows where the "1st party" column has the value "conservative". The rows where this condition is true are at indices 2, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, and 10.
   3. In each of these rows, we look for the "2nd member" column. The values in this column for these rows are "thomas dyke acland", "william gore - langton", "(not provided)", "sir alexander fuller - acland - hood , bt", "hon arthur hood", "mordaunt bisset", and "charles isaac elton" respectively.
   4. To determine if "charles isaac elton" was the 2nd member when the 1st party (conservative) was in power, we compare this value to the values found in step 3 for rows where the 1st party was conservative. In this case, the match is found at row index 10.
   5. Since "charles isaac elton" matches the value of the "2nd member" column in a row where the 1st party is "conservative", our conclusion is that he was indeed the 2nd member when the 1st party was conservative.

   Final answer:
